links.title: Mobile phone tracking - Wikipedia
links.description: Mobile phone tracking is a process for identifying the location of a mobile phone, whether stationary or moving. Localization may occur either via multilateration of radio signals between (several) cell towers of the network and the phone, or simply via GPS. links.description: Authorities investigating whether Ola Bini was working with WikiLeaks and Assange as part of attempt to ‘destabilise’ Ecuador

links.title: Ecuadors ambassad i Sverige: Svensk förhörd om Wikileaks-koppling
links.description: En svensk man som påstås vara kopplad till visselblåsarsajten Wikileaks har förhörts av polis i Ecuador. Mannen togs till förhör när han var på väg till Japan. Ecuadors ambassad i Sverige hävdade på eftermiddagen svensk tid att han var släppt, men uppgifterna motsades av landets inrikesminister senare under kvällen.

links.title: LRB · Andrew O’Hagan · Ghosting: Julian Assange
links.description: On 5 January 2011, at 8.30 p.m., I was messing about at home when the phone buzzed on the sofa. It was a text from Jamie Byng, the publisher of Canongate. ‘Are you about?’ it said. ‘I have a somewhat left-field idea. It’s potentially very exciting. But I need to discuss urgently.’ . . .

links.title: Conspiracy (criminal) - Wikipedia
18 U.S. Code § 1030 -  Fraud and related activity in connection with computers
Document: Julian Assange Indictment
links.description: On Thursday, the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia unsealed a March 6, 2018 indictment charging Julian Assange, the founder head of WikiLeaks, for conspiring to commit computer intrusions by assisting Chelsea Manning with breaking a U.S. government password. The grand jury charged violations of 18 U.S.C. §§371, 1030(a)(1), 1030(a)(2) and 1030(c)(2)(B)(ii).

links.title: The U.S. Government’s Indictment of Julian Assange Poses Grave Threats to Press Freedom
links.description: The Trump DOJ is exploiting animosity toward Assange to launch a thinly disguised effort to criminalize core functions of investigative journalism.

links.title: Kevin Poulsen on Twitter
links.description:
“Here's Julian Assange's fateful offer to crack a password for Chelsea Manning.

Context: Manning, worried her SIPRnet downloads were being noticed, thought about using someone else's desktop for a while to cover tracks.”

links.title: Jake Williams on Twitter
links.description: “@kpoulsen But he did "send it to our LM guy" - I seriously think that he crossed the line here from journalism to material support. Whether or not he passed the hash (sorry) to his "LM guy" or not, he was clearly offering support for what he knew were illegal activities. 1/2”

links.title: Julian Assange is an activist, not a journalist
links.description: Frida Ghitis writes that Julian Assange's claim that he is a journalist is false, but that will not preclude authoritarian goverments from using his case to thwart the legitimate media.

links.title: Developing and Cultivating Sources
links.description: Find new “suspects.” Seek out sources beyond the “usual suspects” on your beat. If you always find yourself talking to white men, find some women and minorities who might bring a different perspective to your stories and steer you toward different ideas. links.title: 'But I'm not a lawyer. I'm an agent.'
links.description: Just over a quarter century ago, when I was a young scribbler traipsing around the metro desk of the Baltimore Sun, I had an early opportunity to learn a lesson about money, about ethics, about capitalism and, in particular, about the American entertainment industry. And Dorothy Simon, she raised no fools. I only needed to learn it once. I learned about something called 'packaging.' And now, finally, my apostasy from newspapering having delivered...

links.title: Scriptnotes Podcast: 393 - Twenty Questions About the Agency Agreement
links.description: John welcomes WGA negotiation committee members Chris Keyser and Angelina Burnett to answer listener questions on what’s happening and what to expect. We also follow up on the Disney/Fox 2000 merger, why we won’t be saying ‘baby writers’ anymore, and upcoming meeting dates for the WGA. Links:   The Disney – Fox Merger  Upcoming WGA Meeti...
